docx_questions.text: Which statement does not accurately describe the pericardium?
options: The pericardium is a double-walled membranous sac that encloses the heart.
It is made up of connective tissue and a surface layer of squamous cells.
The pericardium protects the heart against infection and inflammation from the lungs and pleural space.
It contains pain and mechanoreceptors that can elicit reflex changes in blood pressure and heart rate.

docx_questions.text: Which cardiac chamber has the thinnest wall and why?
options: The right and left atria; they are low-pressure chambers that serve as storage units and conduits for blood.
The right and left atria; they are not directly involved in the preload, contractility, or afterload of the heart.
The left ventricle; the mean pressure of blood coming into this ventricle is from the lung, which has a low pressure.
The right ventricle; it pumps bNloUoRdSIiNntGoTtBh.eCOpuMlmonary capillaries, which have a lower pressure compared with the systemic circulation.

docx_questions.text: Which chamber of the heart endures the highest pressures?
What is the process that ensures mitral and tricuspid valve closure after the ventricles are filled with blood?
options: hordae tendineae relax, which allows the valves to close.
Increased pressure in the ventricles pushes the valves to close.
Trabeculae carneae contract, which pulls the valves closed.
Reduced pressure in the atria creates a negative pressure that pulls the valves closed.

docx_questions.text: Regarding the heart’s valves, what is a function of the papillary muscles?
options: The papillary muscles close the semilunar valve.
These muscles prevent backward expulsion of the atrioventricular valve.
The papillary muscles open the semilunar valve.

docx_questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, why do the aortic and pulmonic valves close after the ventricles relax?
options: Papillary muscles relax, which allows the valves to close.
hordae tendineae contract, which pulls the valves closed.
Reduced pressure in the ventricles creates a negative pressure, which pulls the valves closed.
lood fills the cusps of the valves and causes the edges to merge, closing the valves.

docx_questions.text: Oxygenated blood flows through which vessel?
Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery during a myocardial infarction would interrupt blood supply to which structures?
options: Left and right ventricles and much of the interventricular septum
Left atrium and the lateral wall of the left ventricle
Upper right ventricle, right marginal branch, and right ventricle to the apex
Posterior interventricular sulcus and the smaller branches of both ventricles

docx_questions.text: Occlusion of the circumflex arteryNdUuRrSinINgGaTmB.yCoOcMardial infarction would interrupt blood supply to which area?
options: Left and right ventricles and much of the interventricular septum
Posterior interventricular sulcus and the smaller branches of both ventricles
Upper right ventricle, right marginal branch, and right ventricle to the apex
Left atrium and the lateral wall of the left ventricle

docx_questions.text: The coronary sinus empties into which cardiac structure?
What is the ratio of coronary capillaries to cardiac muscle cells?
During the cardiac cycle, which structure directly delivers action potential to the ventricular myocardium?
What causes depolarization of a cardiac muscle cell to occur?
options: ecrease in the permeability of the cell membrane to potassium
Rapid movement of sodium into the cell
ecrease in the movement of sodium out of the cell
Rapid movement of calcium out of the cell

docx_questions.text: Which event occurs during phase 1 of the normal myocardial cell depolarization and repolarization?
options: Repolarization when potassium moves out of the cells
Repolarization when sodium rapidly enters into the cells
Early repolarization when sodium slowly enters the cells
Early repolarization when calcium slowly enters the cells

docx_questions.text: Which phase of the normal myocardial cell depolarization and repolarization correlates with diastole?
In the normal electrocardiogram, what does the PR interval represent?
options: trial activation to onset of ventricular activity

docx_questions.text: What period follows depolarization of the myocardium and represents a period during which no new cardiac potential can be propagated?
Which complex (wave) represents the sum of all ventricular muscle cell depolarizations?
What can shorten the conduction time of action potential through the atrioventricular (AV) node?
If the sinoatrial (SA) node fails, then at what rate (depolarizations per minute) can the atrioventricular (AV) node depolarize?
What is the effect of epinephrine on 𝗉3 receptors on the heart?
options: Supplements the effects of both 𝗉1 and 𝗉2 receptors.
Increases the strength of myocardial contraction.
Prevents overstimulation of the heart by the sympathetic nervous system.

docx_questions.text: Where in the heart are the receptors for neurotransmitters located?
What enables electrical impulses to travel in a continuous cell-to-cell fashion in myocardial cells?
Within a physiologic range, what does an increase in left ventricular end-diastolic volume (preload) result in?
Pressure in the left ventricle must exceed pressure in which structure before the left ventricle can eject blood?
Continuous increases in left ventricular filing pressures result in which disorder?

When the volume of blood in the ventricle at the end of diastole increases, the force of the myocardial contraction during the next systole will also increase, which is an example of which law or theory about the heart?
The resting heart rate in a healthy person is primarily under the control of which nervous system?
The Bainbridge reflex is thought to be initiated by sensory neurons in which cardiac location?
After the baroreceptor reflex is stimulated, the resulting impulse is transmitted from the carotid artery by which sequence of events?
options: Vagus nerve to the medulla to increase parasympathetic activity and to decrease sympathetic activity
Glossopharyngeal cranial nerve through the vagus nerve to the medulla to increase sympathetic activity and to deNcrUeRasSeINpGaTraBs.yCmOMpathetic activity
Glossopharyngeal cranial nerve through the vagus nerve to the medulla to increase parasympathetic activity and to decrease sympathetic activity
Glossopharyngeal cranial nerve through the vagus nerve to the hypothalamus to increase parasympathetic activity and to decrease sympathetic activity

docx_questions.text: Reflex control of total cardiac output and total peripheral resistance is controlled by what mechanism?
options: Parasympathetic stimulation of the heart, arterioles, and veins
Sympathetic stimulation of the heart, arterioles, and veins
utonomic control of the heart only
Somatic control of the heart, arterioles, and veins

docx_questions.text: What is the most important negative inotropic agent?
The right lymphatic duct drains into which structure?
Where is the major cardiovascular center in the central nervous system?
What is the major determinant of the resistance that blood encounters as it flows through the systemic circulation?
options: Volume of blood in the systemic circulation

docx_questions.text: Which function of the cardiovascular system is often affected by ischemia?
What physical sign is the result of turbulent blood flow through a vessel?
What is the major effect of a calcium channel blocker such as verapamil on cardiac contractions?
options: Increases the rate of cardiac contractions.
ecreases the strength of cardiac contractions.
Stabilizes the rhythm of cardiac contractions.
Stabilizes the vasodilation during cardiac contractions.

docx_questions.text: An early diastole peak caused by filling of the atrium from peripheral veins is identified by which intracardiac pressure?
Which intracardiac pressure is generated by the atrial contraction?
Which intracardiac pressure is produced because of the descent of the tricuspid valve ring and by the ejection of blood from both ventricles?
